channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: 'Disturbing picture' in slavery case
item.description: Detectives investigating the case of three women allegedly held as slaves for 30 years in south London uncover a "complicated and disturbing picture of emotional control".

item.title: US remembers Kennedy 50 years on
item.description: Flags are lowered, bells toll and wreaths are laid, as the US marks half a century since President John F Kennedy's assassination in Dallas.

item.title: Deaths rise in Latvia store collapse
item.description: Latvian rescuers search for survivors in the rubble of a supermarket in the capital Riga which collapsed on Thursday, killing at least 50.

item.title: Osborne confirms Co-op Bank inquiry
item.description: An independent inquiry into events at the Co-op Bank is confirmed by the chancellor, as the bank's former chairman is arrested over drugs allegations.

item.title: City intern died from epilepsy
item.description: An intern working for Bank of America Merrill Lynch in London died from epilepsy, which could have been triggered by "working so hard", an inquest hears.

item.title: Police to probe undercover Army unit
item.description: Northern Ireland's director of public prosecutions asks the police to investigate a British army unit which it is claimed killed unarmed civilians.

item.title: Kerry to join Iran nuclear talks
item.description: US State Secretary John Kerry is to travel to Geneva later on Friday to help narrow differences in nuclear talks with Iran, officials say.

item.title: Met Commissioner 'would not cycle'
item.description: The Metropolitan Police Commissioner says he would not cycle in London following six fatalities in two weeks.

item.title: Prison deal off amid Serco claims
item.description: Plans to privatise three prisons have been dropped because of an investigation into leading bidder Serco, the justice secretary announces.

item.title: Typhoon Haiyan toll rises over 5,000
item.description: The death toll from Typhoon Haiyan has risen above 5,000, officials in the Philippines say, two weeks after the devastating storm.

item.title: Russia told to free Greenpeace ship
item.description: A UN maritime tribunal orders Russia to free a Greenpeace vessel and 30 people detained after an oil drilling protest in the Arctic.

item.title: Peace priest Father Alec Reid dies
item.description: Fr Alec Reid, who was a key figure in the Northern Ireland peace process, acting as a go-between between the IRA and politicians, has died.

item.title: James Arthur cancels engagements
item.description: X Factor winner James Arthur cancels his engagements for a week due to "acute exhaustion", in the wake of a public relations meltdown on Twitter.

item.title: Queues to buy Beckhams' clothes
item.description: Members of the public have been queuing outside a west London charity shop to buy designer clothes donated by David and Victoria Beckham.

item.title: Mourinho questions ref chief's apology
item.description: Chelsea boss Jose Mourinho criticises referees' chief Mike Riley for apologising to West Bromwich Albion.

item.title: Rosberg beats Red Bulls in practice
item.description: Mercedes driver Nico Rosberg holds off the Red Bulls in a wet second practice session at the Brazilian Grand Prix.

item.title: 'Pathetic' England have gifted Test
item.description: England's batting was "pathetic" as they slumped to 136 all out on the second day of the first Test, says Geoffrey Boycott.

item.title: Is Froch-Groves the new Benn-Eubank?
item.description: Carl Froch versus George Groves brings back memories of Nigel Benn and Chris Eubank's rivalry in the 1990s, says Ben Dirs

item.title: Did England squander their World Cup legacy?
item.description: Ten years on from the World Cup triumph in Sydney, did English rugby fail to capitalise on its golden moment?

item.title: 'Slavery' shock, and JFK still making headlines
item.description: The press reacts to the London "slavery" case, while it's a day for old news - remembering the day John F Kennedy was shot.

item.title: Petrol prices 'continue to fall'
item.description: UK motorists are paying the lowest average petrol prices for more than two and a half years, according to the AA.

item.title: VIDEO: What next for US and UK banks?
item.description: Households and businesses on both sides of the Atlantic want to know what will happen to their loan and mortgage costs over the next few years. Hugh Pym has been discussing the latest signals with Alan Clarke of Scotia Bank and Brian Hilliard of Societe Generale.

item.title: Tories 'fighting for EU referendum'
item.description: Tories are "prepared to go the distance" to legislate for an EU referendum despite Labour blocking tactics in a Commons debate, MP James Wharton says.

item.title: AUDIO: Ed Miliband 'marooned' for Radio 4
item.description: Ed Miliband has attributed his interest in politics to his parents, in an edition of BBC Radio 4's Desert Island Discs.

item.title: Concern at brain haemorrhage delays
item.description: Experts warn of delays in the diagnosis and treatment of patients with brain haemorrhages, especially at weekends, which they say is causing 'unnecessary harm'.

item.title: VIDEO: Hospitals prepare for a winter rush
item.description: Hospitals in England face growing pressure from an increasing number of elderly people being treated as emergency cases, according to the Care Quality Commission.

item.title: Free school faces closure
item.description: One of the first schools to open under England's free school programme is facing closure if it does not come up with a convincing improvement plan in the next two weeks.

item.title: AUDIO: UK 'needs foreign language speakers'
item.description: 5 live reporter Rowan Bridge visits Manchester College to find out why are British students so behind with languages.

item.title: Global launch for Microsoft Xbox One
item.description: The global launch of Microsoft's the Xbox One game console took place early on Friday, 22 November.

item.title: VIDEO: Making Google's Doctor Who doodle
item.description: BBC North America Technology Correspondent Richard Taylor meets the people behind Google's Doctor Who doodle.

item.title: Hope for climate talks' final hours
item.description: Negotiators were preparing for a long final session at the National Stadium in Warsaw as UN talks on climate change crawled to a conclusion.

item.title: AUDIO: Bird alarm: Great tits use predator-specific calls
item.description: Great tits produce different alarm calls depending on whether their nests are threatened my snakes, crows or martens, recordings reveal.

item.title: Jordan collects playwriting honour
item.description: Anna Jordan is named winner of the 2013 Bruntwood Prize for playwriting for her work Yen, an exploration of lost childhood.

item.title: VIDEO: How to win a role in Star Wars
item.description: UK casting agent Kate Bone tells the BBC's Lizo Mzimba what film-makers are looking for, as open casting sessions are due to take place for two roles in Star Wars: Episode VII.

item.title: Rebuilding after 9/11
item.description: Will Self asks whether the new World Trade Center is a fitting memorial.

item.title: The Loop: Duran Duran and those natty ties
item.description: Welcome to the Loop, the Magazine's weekly letters column, including the best of your thoughts on Twitter and Facebook.

item.title: Torch bearer jailed for sex offences
item.description: A man is jailed for child sex offences committed in the 1980s after a victim saw him running in the Olympic Torch relay and reported him.

item.title: Sex change MEP 'threatened by UKIP'
item.description: An MEP tells the BBC she revealed her gender reassignment secret because of threats from journalists and her former colleagues in UKIP.

item.title: RBS chief pledges fundamental change
item.description: The new chief executive of RBS, Ross McEwan, promises fundamental changes in the bank's customer service.

item.title: Schools could delay new Higher exams
item.description: The Scottish government signals that it will allow schools to delay the introduction of the new Higher exams for fifth year pupils.

item.title: Woman 'held captive for ten years'
item.description: A malnourished woman with learning disabilities was allegedly raped repeatedly and imprisoned for almost a decade, the High Court hears.

item.title: Latest phase of Haass talks end
item.description: The latest phase of the talks chaired by the former US envoy Richard Haas have finished in Belfast.

item.title: Teacher jailed over sex with pupil
item.description: A teacher is jailed for two years after a secret four-year relationship with a 14-year-old female pupil.

item.title: Search for family of war bomber crew
item.description: A search begins to find relatives of an airman from Pontypridd and other six crew of a World War Two bomber which has been discovered in a remote German forest.

item.title: Zimbabwe deadline for foreign firms
item.description: The owners of foreign firms operating in Zimbabwe in sectors from farming to hairdressing will be arrested after 1 January 2014, a senior official warns.

item.title: SA papers defy Zuma house photo ban
item.description: South African papers publish images of President Jacob Zuma's residence, defying a government warning that this would break security laws.

item.title: China 'flies first stealth drone'
item.description: China successfully flies a stealth drone for the first time on Thursday, state media say, citing eyewitness reports.

item.title: 'Five killed' in Karachi bomb blasts
item.description: At least five people are reported to have been killed in two bomb explosions in a busy area of Pakistan's southern city of Karachi.

item.title: Prodigy is new world chess champion
item.description: Norwegian chess prodigy Magnus Carlsen, 22, becomes the world champion, beating title holder Viswanathan Anand of India.

item.title: Ukraine rallies over snub to EU
item.description: Thousands of protesters stage rallies across Ukraine, angry at the government's decision to delay a landmark agreement with the EU.

item.title: Colombia Santos seeks vice-president
item.description: Colombia's President, Juan Manuel Santos, announces a re-election bid but his vice-president says he will not stand for the 2014 poll.

item.title: Venezuela leader gets special powers
item.description: Venezuela's congress gives final approval to controversial legislation allowing President Nicolas Maduro to govern by decrees for 12 months.

item.title: Syrian rebels form new Islamic Front
item.description: Seven leading Islamist rebel groups in Syria join forces in an effort to show a united front after weeks of major advances by government forces.

item.title: Newborn lion cubs die in Gaza zoo
item.description: Two lion cubs die just two days after their birth in a zoo in the Gaza Strip, with staff blaming inexperience and a lack of medicine.

item.title: US prepares for more online gambling
item.description: Online gambling is launched in the state of New Jersey, a sign that the US may slowly be opening up to the multibillion-dollar industry.

item.title: North Korea confirms US citizen held
item.description: North Korea confirms it is holding a US citizen, amid concern for an 85-year-old man who was reportedly detained on a visit there last month.

item.title: Week in pictures: 16-22 November 2013
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: Day in pictures: 22 November 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 22 November

item.title: In pictures: Latvia store collapse
item.description: Rescue efforts continue in Latvian capital Riga

item.title: Tokyo Motor Show: New cars unveiled
item.description: Carmakers unveil concepts in Tokyo

item.title: Your pictures: Masks
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of masks

item.title: In pictures: Portrait Salon 2013
item.description: A selection of this year's pictures

item.title: In pictures: The Hidden Mother
item.description: Keeping a child in front of the lens

item.title: In pictures: Beirut blasts
item.description: Double bombing in Lebanese capital

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The prime minister says there are "no plans" for an amnesty on crimes during the Troubles.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Justin Bieber' of chess wins title
item.description: Norwegian prodigy Magnus Carlsen has been called the Justin Bieber of chess after becoming the chess world champion at the age of 22.

item.title: VIDEO: Iconic images from day JFK was shot
item.description: On the 22nd of November 1963, America changed forever when President John F Kennedy was assassinated, but iconic images of that fateful day live on.

item.title: VIDEO: New eyes for boy injured in attack
item.description: A Chinese boy whose eyes were gouged out in an attack in August has undergone surgery to complete the process of implanting prosthetic eyes.

item.title: VIDEO: HMS Illustrious sets off for Philippines
item.description: HMS Illustrious is bringing 500 tonnes of aid to survivors of Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines.

item.title: VIDEO: Matt Smith on perils of being recognised
item.description: Matt Smith, who plays the Doctor, explains how once while answering the call of nature he was spotted by a fan who wanted him to speak to his wife.

item.title: VIDEO: Sell it like Beckham - for charity
item.description: Designer clothes donated by David and Victoria Beckham have sold out at a charity shop in London to raise money for the Philippines.

item.title: VIDEO: The appeal of driving £2m trams
item.description: Edinburgh's tram drivers are being put through their paces ahead of the new service opening in spring 2014.

item.title: VIDEO: 'I never thought this day would come'
item.description: A British woman arrested by Russian authorities during a Greenpeace protest in the Arctic is freed on bail after two months in detention.

item.title: The pressure of body image on women
item.description: Why do successful women feel pressure to look a certain way?

item.title: Modern day slavery in the UK
item.description: How widespread is servitude - and what's being done about it?

item.title: How did Doctor Who reflect the news?
item.description: How did Doctor Who reflect events in the real world?

item.title: A side-effect of China's one-child policy
item.description: What's it like growing up without a brother, sister or cousin?

item.title: The tweet that sparked a debate over racism in Norway
item.description: The Somali student who started a hot debate in Norway

item.title: Consoles: One box to rule them all?
item.description: The titanic battle for control of the living room

item.title: Australia revel in 'payback time'
item.description: Ruthless Australian display brings Ashes series to life

item.title: The new meaning of spyware
item.description: What happens when spooks use hacker tools?

item.title: Remembering Benjamin Britten at 100
item.description: Memories of a music genius and private man

item.title: Quiz of the week's news
item.description: Which farmyard animals crashed through a woman's roof?

item.title: How damaged is Co-op Bank by Flowers furore?
item.description: How Co-op made the hedge funds look good

item.title: Can my doctor be my Facebook friend?
item.description: Can your doctor be your Facebook friend too?
